resources.string: Select the location of the /dat folder where vesselData.xml is located. Warning: Changing the location while connected to a server will reset the connection.

Before you can use Artemis Messenger, you must have an Artemis server running. Open Artemis on your computer and click "Start Server". After that, enter the server\'s address into the Address bar at the top of your screen, then touch the Connect button on the right to connect to the server.

Artemis Messenger is a Comms client app designed to be used with Artemis Spaceship Bridge Simulator, developed by Thom Robertson. It will be your assistant in managing side missions, ally ships, stations and more.
Welcome to Artemis Messenger! If this is your first time using this app, this tutorial will teach you all you need to know about how to use it.

You will know that the connection was successful if the area around the Address bar turns green. You will probably also see text appear in the box below it; that is the ship selector box. Touch it to switch to any of the eight ships; you will then assume a Comms role for that ship.

If you touch the Home button on your phone to return to your Home menu, Artemis Messenger will keep running in the background. It will continue to receive information about side missions, allies and stations via a Comms service. This information will be shown as notifications on your phone. If you click on one of those notifications, you will return to Artemis Messenger.

When you want to leave Artemis Messenger, just hit the Back button on your phone. If your phone doesn\'t have a Back button, you can also press the Close button in the top-right corner of the screen. If the app is connected to a server, a dialog will appear asking if you want to close the connection; otherwise, no dialog will appear.
Special thanks to Robert J. Walker for writing the IAN (Interface for Artemis Networking) library, without which this app could not exist. IAN is available on GitHub.

While running the Artemis Messenger app, touch the Missions button to open the Missions view. This is where you can see all of the side missions that are currently running. Whenever you start Artemis Messenger, the Missions view is open by default.
Extra Coolant: Engineering will receive two additional units of coolant to use as desired.
Nuclear Missiles: Your ship will receive two additional Type 4 Nuke torpedoes.
Production Speed: The station that issued the side mission will begin producing torpedoes twice as fast.
X45 Terran Science Vessel\nHelp us help you.\nFirst, rendezvous with D13 and download some data we need. Then, rendezvous with us, and we\'ll give you more engineering coolant.

This message gives you the following information. First, you are being told to go to D13 and rendezvous with them. Second, after that, you must go to X45, the sender of the message. Finally, your reward is that they will give you more engineering coolant.

When this information is received, it is organized into the Missions table. The Source is the location to visit first, the Destination is the location to visit second, and the Reward is what you will receive. The possible rewards are as follows.
Battery Charge: Your ship will receive some additional energy.

Side missions occur during a running simulation and offer the player an opportunity to acquire various bonuses that last for the remainder of the simulation. These side missions are issued to the Comms officer by an ally ship or station, and include instructions to visit another ship or station before going there to receive a reward. For example, Comms may receive a message like this:
Shield Boost: The front and rear shield capacities of your ship will be increased.

The Missions table compresses itself as much as possible by merging entries with the same Source and Destination. In this way, a single entry may show multiple rewards. If a reward would be received more than once, a \"x2\" or similar multiplier will be shown for that reward. Be sure to pay attention to all rewards shown within a single entry.

During a side mission, the next location to visit will be shown in orange. For example, if that location is the Source, you must go there in order to start the mission, at which point the Destination will become orange. After reaching the Destination, thereby completing the mission, the entire row will turn green. After this, you can touch that row to remove it from the table.
There are three columns in the Allies table. The Ship column shows the ship\'s name, the Shields column shows its front and rear shield strengths, and the Status column shows the status of the ship.
While running the Artemis Messenger app, touch the Allies button to open the Allies view. This view shows the statuses of all of the ally ships in the currently running simulation.
Fighter trap: The ship is a disguised fleet of fighters. Do not approach the ship under any circumstances. Destroy it from a distance.
Mine trap: The ship is programmed to self-destruct when your ship approaches. Do not approach the ship under any circumstances. Destroy it from a distance.

Hostages: The ship has been taken over and the crew is being held hostage. To save them, fly near the ship with at least 900 units of energy, which will be given to the captors, and the ship will reward you by enhancing your shield generators. If you have less than 900 units of energy, the ship will self-destruct.

Commandeered: The ship has been taken over by a hostile force. To save the ship, you must approach the ship while it is in a nebula. If you approach while the ship is not in a nebula, it will self-destruct.

As with the Missions view, Artemis Messenger obtains information about the status of the ship via incoming Comms messages. Whenever it connects to a running simulation, it sends a hail message to all ally ships, and then they respond with their status. The status information includes whether or not they have energy to spare, which can be acquired by simply flying near them. In Deep Strike, the ship will also tell you if it has extra torpedoes on board. You can touch a row in the table to manually send a hail message to that ship.
Delivering reward: The ship is headed to a station to drop off some extra torpedoes. Interact at your own discretion.
Flying blind: The ship is stuck. You can fix this by sending it to a station.
Malfunction: The ship\'s computers are down, leaving the ship stranded. You can fix this by firing a Type 9 EMP torpedo at the ship, which will reboot its computer system.

In addition to energy and torpedoes, the Status column also displays the number of current side missions that involve the ship. Finally, the ally ships will report their current status, and Artemis Messenger will display this status and any recommendations for interaction. The statuses the ships may report are as follows.
Normal: The ship is just fine. Interact at your own discretion.
Need 100 energy: The ship is out of energy and cannot move. You can fix this by flying near the ship with at least 100 units of energy, which will be transferred to the ship.
Need DamCon teams: The ship is damaged and needs repair. You can fix this by flying near the ship.
While running the Artemis Messenger app, touch the Stations button to open the Stations view. This view shows all of the docking stations in the currently running simulation.

Like with the Missions and Allies views, Artemis Messenger obtains ordnance information for each station from incoming Comms messages. When the app connects to a running simulation, it sends a message to each station, and the station responds with a status report. This also happens when the player ship docks, undocks, orders a new type of ordnance to be built, or the station finishes building a torpedo.

There are two columns in the Stations table. The Station column shows the name and type of each station, its shield strength, the number of replacement fighters on board, the number of side missions that involve it, and whether or not you are docked there or if the crew is standing by, or even if the station is the closest one to you. The Ordnance column shows the current stock of all ordnance types and an indication of what ordnance is currently being built and how long it will take to finish.
While running the Artemis Messenger app, touch the wrench next to the ship selection box to open the Settings menu. This is where you can change your preferences about how the app behaves.

Artemis Messenger requires a copy of the vesselData.xml file that Artemis uses. There is already a copy bundled with the app, so if you want to use it, change the location to Default. If you want to use your own, change the location to Internal storage or External storage, as appropriate. This is useful if you are running a mod. If vesselData.xml is missing at that location, Artemis Messenger will copy its own files there.

In addition to stops for side missions, the Routing table can also include ally ships that must be visited for other reasons. These ally ships might have spare energy for the player ship, or they might require assistance because they are low on energy, need a DamCon team, are experiencing a malfunction, or have been taken hostage.

There are also some options for sorting the entries in the Allies table in almost any order imaginable. Most of the sorting options available are based on an ally ship\'s name, vessel class and/or status. It is also possible to require that allies with energy are located higher in the table than ships without energy.

There may be some side missions that you would prefer to ignore, especially if they offer rewards that do not interest you. You can remove those missions from the Missions table using the reward filters. When a filter is activated, any side mission that offers the corresponding reward will be shown. For example, a mission offering Battery Charge and Extra Coolant will be shown if either filter is activated; if both are off, it will be hidden. Touch Show All to activate all filters.

While running the Artemis Messenger app, touch the Route button to open the Route view. In this view, you will be shown the minimum distance route to take in order to complete all side missions currently in the Missions view.

There are two columns in the Route table. The Destination column shows the names of the locations to visit, in order from top to bottom, according to the routing algorithm, as well as each location\'s reason(s) for being included. The Direction column shows the direction and distance from the player ship to each stop. As each stop is visited, the appropriate entries in the Route table will disappear.

Note that the route you are given is the route of minimum distance, which is not necessarily the optimal route. For example, the algorithm does not know the locations of potential hazards such as black holes, mines or space monsters. Also, for efficiency, the optimal route is not necessarily calculated exactly; instead, it is randomized and may require several iterations to become optimal.
If you touch a station\'s entry row in the table, the app will send a message to that station to stand by for docking.

Underneath the list of ordnances at each station, the Ordnance column shows the type of ordnance that station is currently building, and the amount of time in which the ordnance is expected to be ready. This amount of time is calculated based on the ordnance\'s type and the station\'s current production speed, which varies based on the type of station. The production speed increases whenever a Production Speed side mission is completed; the number of times a station\'s production speed has increased is also indicated in this column. If the expected completion time for an ordnance differs from its actual completion time, the app will recalibrate the station\'s perceived speed based on the difference. This recalibration may be incorrect if the app is connected to a simulation in progress, but it will eventually correct itself.

When Artemis Messenger is running in the background, the Comms service keeps you updated on side missions using notifications. You can make Artemis Messenger play different ringtones whenever such a notification is made. There are three types of notifications: New side mission, Arrived at source and Arrived at destination.
Choose the method of sorting entries in the Allies table.

You can also access the Help menu from the Settings menu by touching Show help topics. If you access the Help menu in this way, you will return to the Settings menu when you leave. By default, the Help menu is set to display whenever you start up Artemis Messenger; you can turn off this function by touching Show help at startup.

You can gain additional information about a waypoint from the colour of its entry row in the Routing table. Commandeered allies will appear red, damaged allies and stations will appear yellow, malfunctioning allies that are also in the route for another reason appear green, allies that are only malfunctioning appear orange, and all other waypoints appear blue.
